title: Python Stack
text:
Preface
This is a Quarto book.
To learn more about Quarto books visit https://quarto.org/docs/books.

title: 1¬† Python, VS Code, Quarto
text:
2.1 Install Python

2.1.1 Search Engine

Search ‚ÄúPython for VS Code‚Äù
Go to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/python
Click ‚ÄúPython Tutorial‚Äù
Click ‚ÄúInstall Python for python.org‚Äù



2.1.2 Python.org

Click ‚ÄúDownload Python 3.XX.X‚Äù
Open the installer from Downloads
Check both boxes when the ‚ÄúSetup‚Äù prompt comes up.
After the install, select ‚ÄúDisable path length limit‚Äù



2.1.3 Test Python

Windows Key
Type ‚Äúterminal‚Äù
In terminal, type ‚Äúpython‚Äù
In Python, type:


print("hello world")

hello world

title: 1¬† Python, VS Code, Quarto
text:
2.2 Install VS Code

2.2.1 Aside

It is of great benefit to us as learners that VS Code includes ‚ÄúCopilot‚Äù (LLM) integration.



2.2.2 Install

Go to https://code.visualstudio.com/
Click ‚ÄúDownload for Windows‚Äù
Open the installer from Downloads
Check all four boxes when the ‚ÄúSetup‚Äù prompt comes up.
After the install, select ‚ÄúLaunch Visual Studio Code‚Äù



2.2.3 VS Code Setup

Use Copilot, or don‚Äôt.
Choose your theme
Select ‚ÄúBrowse Language Extensions‚Äù

Select ‚ÄúPython‚Äù

Keep this window open

Select ‚ÄúJupyter‚Äù
Optionally, look into R in Visual Studio Code

Click through the remaining options.



2.2.4 Python extension setup

Create a new Python project
Create a new folder, likely Documents/DATA505
Create a file ‚Äúhello.py‚Äù:



hello.py

# hello.py

print("hello world")


Click the [>] button to run the file, which should print out to the terminal:

hello world

Return to the Python tutorial.

Click ‚ÄúCSelect Python Interpreter‚Äù
Select the version of Python you installed earlier.

title: 1¬† Python, VS Code, Quarto
text:
2.3 Install Quarto

2.3.1 Search Engine

Search ‚ÄúQuarto‚Äù
Go to https://quarto.org/
Click ‚ÄúGet Started‚Äù
Click ‚ÄúDownload Quarto CLI‚Äù



2.3.2 Install Quarto

Run the Installer

All default options are fine.

Install the VS Code Extension.

Go to https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=quarto.quarto
Click the ‚ÄúInstall‚Äù button.
Allow the installation in VS Code and your browser.

Setup Python for Quarto

title: 1¬† Python, VS Code, Quarto
text:
2.4 Install Jupyter
*To work with .qmd files, Python needs a package akin to R ‚Äúlanguageserver‚Äù

Go to https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/hello/vscode.html
Run the following terminal command:

If you lost your terminal, create a new one from the menu.

py -m pip install jupyter matplotlib plotly

This will take a moment.

Following the Quarto tutorial, make hello.qmd
Click ‚ÄúRun Cell‚Äù in hello.qmd on this cell:


import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()







Figure¬†2.1: A line plot on a polar axis






When prompted, install the ipykernel
I restarted VS Code.

title: 1¬† Python, VS Code, Quarto
text:
2.5 Cleanup

2.5.1 Quarto Preview

To test whether the process worked, open hello.qmd in VS Code.
Quarto preview hello.qmd either by pressing [>] or by using ctrl+shift+k.
After a moment, a document will be displayed, in VS Code and if you wish, in browser.



2.5.2 Render .md
To make this document.

Prefix the .md document with a .qmd header:

---
title: "Python, VS Code, Quarto"
format:
  html:
    code-fold: true
jupyter: python3
---

Rename from fname.md to fname.qmd

I did this by creating a new file and using copy+paste

Use quarto render fname.qmd either:

In the VS Code integrated terminal, or
At the command line, e.g.¬†Windows Key+‚Äúterminal‚Äù

title: 2¬† Quarto Books and GitHub Pages
text:
3 Quarto Books and GitHub Pages

3.0.1 Search Engine

Search ‚ÄúQuarto Books‚Äù
Go to https://quarto.org/docs/books/



3.0.2 At the Terminal

Created a folder called ‚Äúwork‚Äù.
I ran the following in the terminal:



Terminal

quarto create project book mybook


I will be prompted for a title

I used ‚ÄúPython Stack‚Äù

I will be prompted if I want to open in vscode

I accepted.




3.0.3 In VS Code

Generating the book project automatically generated a _quarto.yml file.



_quarto.yml

project:
  type: book

book:
  title: "mybook"
  author: "Jane Doe"
  date: "8/18/2021"
  chapters:
    - index.qmd
    - intro.qmd
    - summary.qmd
    - references.qmd

bibliography: references.bib

format:
  html:
    theme: cosmo
  pdf:
    documentclass: scrreprt
  epub:
    cover-image: cover.png


I updated the file to be as follows, with only two chapters:



_quarto.yml

project:
  type: book

book:
  title: "Python Stack"
  author: "Prof. Calvin"
  date: "1/9/2025"
  chapters:
    - index.qmd
    - VSCode.qmd
    - Books.qmd

format:
  html:
    theme: cosmo
  pdf:
    documentclass: scrreprt



3.0.4 Creating Content

I view the initial book by opening a .qmd file and using Preview

By default on Windows, Crtl+Shift+K

I include some content in my new .qmd files.

For me, this was a prior lecture ‚ÄúPython, VS Code, Quarto‚Äù
For me, this was this .qmd on books & pages.

I use a full render after creating content to ensure everything is up-to-date.



Terminal

quarto render




4 On GitHub
Follow this guide

4.0.1 Publish Content to GitHub Pages

Search ‚ÄúQuarto Publish‚Äù
Go to https://quarto.org/docs/publishing/github-pages.html
Read the following:


an important pre-requisite: you need to have a Git repository on your local machine that is synced to GitHub.



4.0.2 Create a Git repository

Navigate to https://github.com/
Select the Green Button üñ•Ô∏èNew

It will take you to this url: https://github.com/new

Do some setup:

Select an owner

I am @cd-public

Name the repository

I‚Äôll do ‚Äúpython-stack-book‚Äù

Add a description.

‚ÄúDemo quarto book on the Python tech stack.‚Äù


Select the Green Button Create repository



4.0.3 Create a New Repository on the Command Line

Navigate in the file system to your book directory.

You will need to set up Git at the command line.




4.0.4 Follow the Instruction from Quarto

Return to https://quarto.org/docs/publishing/github-pages.html
Follow instructions from Render to docs up to Publish Command
crumbs: 2¬† Quarto Books and GitHub Pages
